unnormalised: Simply put, rental yield is the percentage return you get on your property investment based on the rent you collect annually. To calculate it:
normalised: (Annual Rental Income divided by Property Value) multiplied by one hundred

So, if you bought a flat in, say, Bangalore for rupee fifty lakhs and rent it out for rupee twenty thousand a month (rupee two point four lakhs annually), your gross rental yield would be (rupee two point four lakhs divided by rupee fifty lakhs) multiplied by one hundred equals four point eight percent.

unnormalised: So, if you bought a flat in, say, Bangalore for Rs. 50 Lakhs and rent it out for Rs. 20,000 a month (Rs. 2.4 Lakhs annually), your gross rental yield would be (Rs. 2.4 Lakhs / Rs. 50 Lakhs) * 100 = 4.8%.
normalised: Now, what is considered "good"? It varies! Generally, anything above five percent is considered decent in many Indian cities. But location matters massively. A six percent yield in a Tier-two city like Coimbatore might be easier to achieve than a four percent yield in a prime Mumbai location.
